alert.note: Alert for Koochiching (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Duluth (Northeast Minnesota and Northern Wisconsin)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 31 at 2:45PM CDT until further notice by NWS Duluth
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM CDT MONDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues. Namakan and Rainy Lake have both surpassed levels set during the 2014 peak levels. * WHERE...Portions of north central Minnesota and northeast Minnesota, including the following counties, in north central Minnesota, Koochiching. In northeast Minnesota, Lake and St. Louis. * WHEN...Until 400 PM CDT Monday. * IMPACTS...Flooding of lakes, rivers, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Several structures are flooded and some sand bagging operations are continuing. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 232 PM CDT, Emergency management reported ongoing extensive flooding. - Thunderstorms brought 1 to 4 inches of new rainfall to the Rainy River Basin over the holiday weekend. While mostly dry weather is expected this week, rises will likely continue. Namakan and Kabetogama Lakes were at 1122.2 feet as of May 30, which is 20.5 inches above the peak level set in 2014. The level of Namakan Lake is expected to rise another 2 to 3 inches in the next few days before it may begin to crest and fall early next week. Rainy Lake was at 1112.4 feet as of May 30, 12 inches above the 2014 flooding peak and only 7 inches away from the record level set in 1950. Rainy Lake is expected to rise another 8 to 11 inches over the next week, breaking the 1950 record. A peak is unlikely before mid-June on Rainy Lake. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... International Falls, Winton, Kabetogama, Crane Lake, Buyck, Voyageurs National Park, Rainy Lake East, Kabetogama Lake, Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Near Trout Lake, Burntside Lake, Rainy Lake West, Fall Lake, Birch Lake, Basswood Lake, western Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, Ranier, Johnson Lake, Sand Point Lake and Echo Lake. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood http://www.weather.gov/dlh/RainyRiverBasin
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Once levels have peaked, it will take a matter of weeks to a month for levels to decline to near normal summer levels. Additional rainfall will prolong the time it takes for levels to recede.
